Dedicated review lectures such as this one are so helpful. They are certainly useful for tying everything together and identifying remaining questions that students may have. However, at least in my experience this kind of lecture also has some psychological benefits, at least for some students, because they end up realizing they actually know most of the material. This is very important since what often holds students back is lack of confidence and overcomplicating things. And of course a review lecture by Prof. Strang himself is extra special!

My answear to the misunderstood question was actually wrong after i tried it for my self.  This is the correct answear just for the fun of it: Question : can (1,2,3) be a vector in the null space A: yes it can, I will give u an other version of that vector but similar : v = (3,2,1) A matrix that would produce this vector v to be in the null space would be A = [(1,1,2),(3,4,1),(-9,-11,-8)] try it for your self dear patient reader and you will say ''aha!''

You can do this for any vector in general. For a given vector v you can always construct a matrix A whose null space contains v and it can be constructed systematically.   You can also systematically construct any matrix whose null space contains any finite set of vectors as long as the vectors don’t form a full rank matrix
Reduce it to row reduced echelon form…you will get three pivot columns……meaning these pivot columns are independent …therefore invertible.

No. It is a bit counterintuitive.   In general, the column space does change. And when we multiply A and x to give 0 (Ax = 0), the 0 vector on the right hand side results from a combination of the columns of A. So you might think that since the column space is different, you'll need a different combination of the columns to give 0.   But later you'll learn that when Ax=0, x is perpendicular to all the rows of A (the dot product of any row of A and x gives 0). So if you change the order of the rows in A, this property still holds i.e. x will still be perpendicular to all the rows of A. And so the null space does not change.   But the left null space does change in general.

I'm still undecided about the time effectiveness of review lectures.  In my classes, lecture time is a limited and valuable resource. Students who have kept pace with the reading, lectures, and homeworks already know 90% of the material on the review.  Students who have procrastinated learning (memorizing) the material will be lost during much of the review and won't get much out of it.  You might as well just give students a list of topics or problems that could be on the exam, and let them manage their own time.  Good students will come to office hours or message (email) you if they have questions.
View the complete course: http://ocw.mit.edu/18-06S05. Best wishes on your studies!
what was echelon form

In case you're still interested in an answer 5months after your question: We know that the vector (0,0,1) was in the nullspace. The vector basically  says take 0 of column1, add 0 of column 2 and add 1 of column3. The last column, column3, then has to be (0,0,0) otherwise it wouldnt give you the zero vector and therefor would not be part of the nullspace. Same thing with the 2nd column: We know that (1,1,0) is in the nullspace and it again basically just says take 1 of column1, add 1 of column2 and add 0 of column3. Since Column1 is (1,2,1) then column2 has to be (-1,-2,-1) to give the zero vector. Otherwise (1,1,0) wouldn't be in the nullspace, which we know it is.

The equation you are attempting to solve is Bx=[101]. If you actually multiply the given matrices to find B, you will see that it’s first column is [101]. So, you need x to equal something that when multiplied times B will give you the first column of B, because that first column of B is the same as the right hand side of the equation Bx=[101]. This x would be [1000] because that would be the same as a combination of 1 of the first column of B, and 0 of the rest of the columns.

Island Cave I have the same feeling, but I kept hearing that the teaching style is amazing, but it is just not for me. Maybe you do.   But if you want to follow better through his lectures, I suggest that you give the first 3 lectures huge importance because a lot of the shortcuts he is doing is based off those lectures. It is the build up of the basic foundational concepts that make some other things easy.  For example, in determining if a matrix is invertible: In the earlier lectures, Prof Strang said that matrices can be seen as a set of operations that are acted to another matrix. An example is the elimination matrix E, we use it to change the rows of another matrix. Given that, what if we want to reverse those operations? This is where inverse matrices come in, the inverse of E is the matrix that will reverse/inverse the operations of E itself, that is where the term "Inverse" comes from. So another way of seeing it is (inverse of E) * E * A = A or (inverse of E) * E = I since I * A = A.  Then, how do we know if a matrix is invertible (that is, its operations can be reversed)? It is invertible if there doesn't exist a linear combination of the columns of A that is the zero vector except the zero combination. Why is that so? One of the easiest way to reason with it is explained in the earlier lectures: if Ax = 0 and A is invertible, then we can multiply both sides by the inverse of A and we will get x = inverse of A * 0 or x = 0. Therefore the value of x should only be zero for the right hand side to be zero.  There a lot of other ways (and better ways, for intuition) to think of this, and the other lectures give insight to that.  But now, you can easily see if a matrix is invertible or not by just looking at its columns, if it's small enough.  =================================================================================================================================================  In order to understand how he multiplies matrices so easily, you need to understand the point of the first 3 lectures. The third lecture is where he explains 4 ways to think of matrix multiplication, if you understand this lecture then it will be easier to follow through how he multiplies them easily.

What you need is practice. You can't expect it to fully understand everything just by watching lectures. I'd recommend that you solve problems available on MIT OCW on Linear Algebra, and focus heavily on the first few lectures which are crucial to understanding this 'tricks' that prof. Strang does.

Yes I can totally understand that this course is actually not optimal for beginners. But after I heard my first introductory course on linear algebra where I practised formalism, simple transformations and proofs over the length of one semester, I dont have any problem to follow him. The traditional university courses are also important in order to learn vocabulary, abstract formalism and of course practice. But the traditional mathematically rigourous way of teaching lacks the ability to put everything together and give an intuition which is what this lecture is trying to do. But yes, the speed of this lecture assumes that you are already cozy and dont have to think much when hearing certain concepts like invertability.  I mean invertability sounds like an easy concept, yeah the effect of a matrix can be undone, but thinking of all the implications it brings when hearing "invertible" takes time. Also spaces and subspaces for example: of course it is introduced in this course but in order to actually know how spaces really behave one should spend some weeks in university doing group theory otherwise you get kind of overwhelmed.

(I was having the same trouble) I think in the initial lectures there were some facts which you should prove it yourself( just take a general small example and see it) to understand everything better- (1) No. of pivots r of any matrix = No. of independent column vectors (2) No. of pivots r does not change if you transpose the matrix. I think more than half of linear algebra goes around the concept of pivots and what they mean. You can tell so many things about a matrix just by observing no. Of pivots.( Dim, null space, left nul space, row space) and once you get the idea of determining the no. Pivots( simple elimination) , you can hear what any (small) matrix want to say without calculations. Also the examples taken by Prof Strang are easy ones, they contain so many one's and zero's  so it's easy to do many things without calculations.
after some time you’ll get good at this. It’ll be just like a reflex if you practice enough.

​ @AntifachoOi not true, because the example the prof gave was two invertible matrices (same size 6x6) can have the same 4 subspaces and be completely different (because it is the fact that they are invertible that gives them the same for subspaces) (please correct if wrong)

Since A and B have same row space then A and B can be made to have same row reduced echelon form and similarly for matrices A^T and B^T. Let r be the rank for both matrices A and B, then there are r independent rows spanning the entire row space for A and B. Then each row vector in row reduced echelon form of B (rref(B)) can be expressed as linear combination of r independent rows of rref(A). If V1,V2,...,Vr be these independent rows of rref(A), then each row vector of rref(B) can be expressed  in some form similar to a1*V1+a2*V2+...+ar*Vr and doing some algebraic manipulations each rows of rref(B) can be made to yield the same matrix as rref(A). SImilar results apply for rref(A^T)=rref(B^T). I don't know if this is leading us to somewhere.

Same RREF. Proof: 1. Given that A and B have the same 4 subspaces, A and B have the same Rank. 2. Since Rank(A) = Rank(B), in RREF the first r columns of RREF(A) = RREF(B) 3. Row operations do not change the row space (since we are just taking linear combinations of the row vectors), hence the overall rows in RREF(A) = RREF(B)     We know this because the first r components are equal, and they must have the same row space, so the remaining m-r components must also be equal. 4. Since rows are same in RREF, the RREFs are equal.
Because any 5x5 matrix can be generated by 25 separate matrices each having a single 1 in a different place.

The Matrix above is 3x4 with 2 Pivots (the 1s in the first and second column). The last two columns without pivots are "connected" with the free 3rd and 4th components x3 and x4. To construct a basis vector for the null space, you make one vector per free column and set the corresponding component to 1 and the other free components to 0 (resulting in (? ? 1 0) and (? ? 0 1)). Then you fill out the missing components with the negative values from the column 3 and 4.   This is explained in the corresponding lecture, where the null space is being introduced (Think its lecture 6-7, Chapter 3.2 in the book)

Your argument shows that a "nullvector" of D is automatically a "nullvector" of CD; that is, N(D) is a subset of N(CD).   However, a "nullvector" of CD is not necessarily a "nullvector" of D if C is singular. It is because a singular matrix may kill a nonzero vector. In other words, it is possible that C(Dx) = 0 could come with Dx ≠ 0.

How? He's so scattered in the way he presents things, and after watching 13 lectures, I feel like I have learned what he taught in a swiss cheese sort of way.

@islandcave8738  I know Prof Strang has an informal, offhand way of talking about things, but it's his way connecting with everyone's first blush insight into the problems and situations. He focuses in on the fundamental ideas that are the foundation of linear algebra, and explains why and how they arise. For me, the first few times I tried to learn linear algebra it seemed like swiss cheese to me too, but as I gained and understanding and went over stuff again, I came to realize how the substance and holes really formed a neat pattern of connections between the different ideas that are at the heart of the subject. I've never seen anyone teach it better. He motivates everything with reasons that are as easy to convey as it gets. Try watching someone else teach it; you'll see what I mean. Also, try going back over the lectures again, from the beginning...

@islandcave8738  to add to what @jonahansen has said, I would also suggest you make your own notes with the videos if you are not doing that. Try solving some problems from his Strang's book after each lecture and see if that aids your understanding.

Look at the solution for x - it's made up of one particular solution and two special solutions from two free variables.  That tells you the null space has dimension two (it's a plane that passes through the origin so it's a subspace).  The particular solution will shift this plane away from the origin. That's just a matrix equation ... put the vector on the right in an augmented matrix, row-reduce.

Because A.[0 0 1] = [0 0 0], that means A's 1st column x 0 + A's 2nd column x 0 + A's last column x 1, then the last column of A must be [0 0 0] A.[1 1 0] = 0, then the second column of A must be -1 of A's first column => A's second column is [-1 -2 -1]

@lucasm4299 It's true, but usually you're penalized only once, at the point you first made a mistake. If the error carries forward consistently, usually you don't get penalized again. At least that's how it is at my university.

1. 18.06 and 18.02 are mandatory for all MIT students. They're not wringers. There are many courses that are very difficult.  2. If you checked out the exams without solving their questions, you're probably not in a good position to assess their difficulty.   3. You're studying this on your own time, at your own pacing. An MIT student takes 3-5 courses a term. It adds up if you don't have excellent time-management or raw talent.

​ @CobaltSthenia  I don't know about many universities, but in my university we have exactly the same workload, and the material that he's teaching is nearly identical, that's why these videos are useful for me to prepare for my exam. I don't watch this stuff because it's from MIT, I watch it because Mr. Strang happens to be an excellent instructor that teaches linear algebra well. And I don't think anybody in the world that studies mathematics, physics, computer sciences, or anything else related, has it easier. I am thankful though that MIT put these videos for free on youtube. That's very forward-thinking, considering this was uploaded in 2009.

​ @CobaltSthenia  3-5 courses a term is pretty standard, at least in the universities I know, both in my own country and abroad.  And I have seen some of the MIT papers. From what I saw,  the difficulty level, very honestly, is pretty standard too, they basically test you on the basics, they normally don't set you something super advanced or esotoric at this level and all of it is based on the material taught in class. What really seems to make the difference, as OP pointed out, seems to be the quality of teaching. And of course, it helps that they usually select the crème de la crème, among the applicants. But many other universities in other countries do that too, often by significantly raising the difficulty level of the entrance tests - such as in India and China - and at the end of three years or four years, the students usually still come out knowing far less than their MIT counterparts. There are several reasons US universities have a Reputation™ :P  and the quality of teaching is one of them. Granted, Mr Strang is obviously among the more brilliant teachers ones even among the Ivy League professors, but if the other professors are even half as good as this guy, I can see why unis like MIT have such a good reputation.

What is the difference between space and subspace?  The dimension of both row and column space of B =[0 1; 0 0] are same, right? So they are both in the R1 subspace. So the subspace of both row and column space is equal, am I right?
@hypnoticpoisons Because those are his reading glasses.

oh i'm still in highschool and i can understand and apply everything he's taught! I was wondering why he was taking his glasses off all the time
@goryans123 This professor is teaching out of a textbook he wrote too.
I love you, professor. it's so important that you're doing this.  it's an absolutely right thing to do. I remember completely different professors and completely corrupted faculty in Russia.
no. As he said, the row-space is span of (0 1)^T, whereas the column-space is span of (1 0)^T.

The dimension of the two spaces is the same. That comes out of the fact that rank (A) = rank (A^T) and here, A is n x n.   But the spaces themselves are in no way the same. In fact, they’re orthogonal. One is spanned by [0 1], the other by [1 0]. So if you think about what that would look like in the 2-dimensional coordinate plane, it’s like the x and y axes. Those are not the same line at all. They’re the furthest thing you can get from being the same line actually, because they’re perpendicular and thus share no directionality whatsoever.  Also, you said the two spaces are “in the R1 subspace” - that’s incorrect. They’re not. They’re subspaces of R2. They’re one-dimensional subspaces, yes, but every element in each respective space has two real number components, so there’s no relation to R1.
